articles.headline: Mueller’s First Indictments Send a Message to Trump
articles.snippet: The gravity of the threat may yet tempt the president to short-circuit the investigation by firing the special counsel or pardoning Paul Manafort or others.
articles.abstract: The gravity of the threat may yet tempt the president to short-circuit the investigation by firing the special counsel or pardoning Paul Manafort or others.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shortly after his former campaign chairman marched into an F.B.I. office to face criminal charges on Monday, President Trump took to Twitter to dismiss their relevance: “There is NO COLLUSION!”

articles.headline: Judge Blocks Trump’s Ban on Transgender Troops in Military
articles.snippet: The strongly worded ruling noted that the Trump administration’s justification for the ban was suspect and likely unconstitutional.
articles.abstract: The strongly worded ruling noted that the Trump administration’s justification for the ban was suspect and likely unconstitutional.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Monday temporarily blocked a White House policy barring military service by transgender troops, ruling that it was based on “disapproval of transgender people generally.”

articles.headline: Trump Is Expected to Name Jerome Powell as Next Fed Chairman
articles.snippet: Jerome H. Powell, a Federal Reserve governor, would replace Janet L. Yellen, whose term expires early next year, two people familiar with the plans said.
articles.abstract: Jerome H. Powell, a Federal Reserve governor, would replace Janet L. Yellen, whose term expires early next year, two people familiar with the plans said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump is expected to nominate Jerome H. Powell as the next chairman of the Federal Reserve, replacing Janet L. Yellen, whose term expires early next year, according to two people familiar with the plans.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Binyamin Appelbaum

articles.headline: Russian Influence Reached 126 Million Through Facebook Alone
articles.snippet: Facebook, Google and Twitter disclosed more about Russian agents’ use of their platforms in the 2016 election as they prepare for hearings before Congress.
articles.abstract: Facebook, Google and Twitter disclosed more about Russian agents’ use of their platforms in the 2016 election as they prepare for hearings before Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russian agents intending to sow discord among American citizens disseminated inflammatory posts that reached 126 million users on Facebook, published more than 131,000 messages on Twitter and uploaded over 1,000 videos to Google’s YouTube service, according to copies of prepared remarks from the companies that were obtained by The New York Times.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: Trump Campaign Got Early Word Russia Had Democrats’ Emails
articles.snippet: George Papadopoulos, a Trump campaign adviser, was told the Russians had “dirt” on Hillary Clinton and “thousands of emails” and were “open for cooperation.”
articles.abstract: George Papadopoulos, a Trump campaign adviser, was told the Russians had “dirt” on Hillary Clinton and “thousands of emails” and were “open for cooperation.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The guilty plea of a 30-year-old campaign aide — so green that he listed Model United Nations in his qualifications — shifted the narrative on Monday of the Trump campaign’s interactions with Russia: Court documents revealed that Russian officials alerted the campaign, through an intermediary in April 2016, that they possessed thousands of Democratic emails and other “dirt” on Hillary Clinton.

articles.headline: Thanks to Wall St., There May Be Too Many Restaurants
articles.snippet: After years of explosive growth, there is a glut of fast-food and casual restaurants, industry experts say. Sales are slumping, and some businesses are faltering.
articles.abstract: After years of explosive growth, there is a glut of fast-food and casual restaurants, industry experts say. Sales are slumping, and some businesses are faltering.
articles.lead_paragraph: PLAINFIELD, Ill. — The way Marcus Mooney saw it, he wasn’t just selling hot dogs — he was selling experiences.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: Tech Executives Are Contrite About Election Meddling, but Make Few Promises on Capitol Hill
articles.snippet: Facebook, Twitter and Google all acknowledged ahead of hearings that Russia’s use of their platforms to sway the American electorate was bigger than previously acknowledged.
articles.abstract: Facebook, Twitter and Google all acknowledged ahead of hearings that Russia’s use of their platforms to sway the American electorate was bigger than previously acknowledged.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Executives from Facebook, Google and Twitter appeared on Capitol Hill for the first time on Tuesday to publicly acknowledge their role in Russia’s influence on the presidential campaign, but offered little more than promises to do better. Their reluctance frustrated lawmakers who sought stronger evidence that American elections will be protected from foreign powers.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang, Nicholas Fandos and Mike Isaac
